Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Leaf Global Fintech: Blockchain-Backed Financial Services for Refugees and Migrants
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to enable secure, digitized financial services. Digitizing financial services lowers the risk of theft associated with carrying cash and greatly reduces exchange and transfer fees. The market is currently estimated at $42 B. The research will assess blockchain’s impact on customers lacking reliable access to cryptocurrency or smartphones. The results could include 60% cost reduction compared to traditional money transfer systems, <30 second transaction completions, and a 0% fraud rate.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to research and develop a blockchain-based money management solution to store, send, and exchange money without a smartphone or internet. Leaf’s core technology includes a blockchain back-end that powers an Unstructured Supplementary Service Data (USSD) front-end, allowing mobile devices to securely send and receive data without an internet connection. Custodial wallets on a public blockchain will provide a transparent and secure ledger. Custom digital representations of value (tokens) pegged to fiat currencies allow portability of assets without exposing users to speculative cryptocurrency risks. In conjunction with a novel identity management system, this solution will create economic identities for users without forfeiting control of sensitive data. Research will evaluate blockchain as a method of legally-compliant money storage and transfer, integrated with the fiat system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Leaf Global is developing a digital financial services platform that will allow those without access to traditional banking services to manage and move money?deposit, withdraw, send international remittances, exchange between currencies?from a basic mobile phone, no smartphone or internet access required. Leaf helps customers manage their money digitally instead of in cash, connect financially with friends and family, and build an economic identity.

The platform addresses the critical need to provide far-reaching, accessible, and affordable money management services to displaced populations and the unbanked. Leaf's services allow migrants and refugees to retain access to money typically lost while leaving their countries and avoid carrying cash while crossing borders without paying high remittance fees. Customers register for a Leaf account in their home country, and add, send, receive, and exchange money anytime through their mobile phone. Once they arrive in the host country, refugees verify their identity and access their Leaf account from any mobile device. Friends and family abroad can also deposit funds into a Leaf customer's account conveniently and affordably. Leaf's solution gives migrants and refugees a better start with financial security, provides digital proof of identification, supports financial literacy, and lessens dependence on host countries and foreign aid. The novel services being developed by Leaf Global leverage existing mobile technology infrastructure and extend its reach far beyond what is currently possible, enabling underserved populations to access financial services and access the formal economy for the first time.

Leaf Global is innovatively applying blockchain technology by combining it with a proprietary Unstructured Supplementary Service Data (USSD) application, which runs on basic phones without advanced functions. USSD technology is like text messaging (SMS) but has more built-in security because users interact in a live session, communicating in real-time in an encrypted channel. All GSM-compliant phones can run USSD, and the technology is already used to conduct financial transactions as part of mobile money systems in many countries. Leaf's integration of USSD technology with existing mobile money solutions allows for money to move in and out of Leaf's system, while the proprietary blockchain-based USSD app enables cross-border storage and movement of assets over a blockchain.

This Phase I research project resulted in the development of identity and privacy management systems and the Wallet product?including the blockchain system, back end, front ends (smartphone application for Android and iOS, USSD application for non-smartphones), and a fiat-to-cryptocurrency exchange. Our Phase I research showed that Leaf's innovative financial services platform for refugees, migrants, and cross-border traders is viable and that potential customers are willing to adopt our product. Leaf's technology can process financial transactions faster, cheaper, and in a more transparent way than current financial systems. Major Phase I highlights include 1) identifying the best blockchain protocol fit for Leaf's needs through blockchain research; 2) making significant progress towards developing a system for managing and verifying customers' identities, as identity verification is a significant challenge in providing financial services to customers in our target markets, where internet connection is not always available; 3) completion of the Wallet product, including servers to manage the creation of wallets/individual blockchain accounts for users and subsequent user actions, servers to manage the fiat-to-crypto exchange, as well as the smartphone and USSD front-end applications; 4) transaction analyses on the fully developed Wallet product, which demonstrated that blockchain can be used in low-connectivity environments for storing both data and value, and is cheaper and faster than traditional money transfer services; 5) integration with all major mobile money providers through a partner telecommunications aggregator; and 6) deployment of a full e-KYC service that allows Leaf to conduct background checks and sanctions screenings on customers even with a refugee ID, which is allowing Leaf to serve the large unbanked population who has also limited access to government-issued IDs. This Phase I project also demonstrated a clear market demand for our product through target customer interviews and usability tests.
